bibl.title: Letter from Kenneth Maxcy to Henry Rose Carter, September 5, 1923

div1.p: Maxcy is glad that Carter is recovering. He discusses the difficulties of distinguishing between re-infection and relapse in malaria, and encloses tables on Coogle's research.

div1.head: Letter from Kenneth Maxcy to Henry Rose Carter, September 5, 1923
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Care of State Health Officer,
Montgomery, Ala.
September 5, 1923.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Badin Hospital,
Badin, N.C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter was a real joy - to know that
you were well on the road to recovery and that your intellect
was just as keen as ever, in spite of your illness.
I sincerely trust, however, that you will “take it easy” for
a long time and give Nature her full chance to make the
needed repairs. She is a wonderful doctor,- if the patient
is not too obstroperous!!!

The approach which you suggest to the
problem of relapses is strategic. It ought to yield
information much more valuable than any that we have at
the present time in this country.

I have the “Digest of the Literature on
Malaria Relapses” prepared by the Rockefeller Foundation.
The abstracts are rather meager, but give me some idea of the
work that has been done by foreigh observers. I note the
observations of Caccini, referred to by you, but Sella is
not quoted (Could it by any chance have been Celli?).
The observations of Stott in Mandalay I should like to look
over more carefully. Perhaps they are better than the others.
- 2 -
Dr. Carter -
It is perfectly obvious that every one is stumped by the difficulty
of distinguishing between reinfections and relapses. This has
beenwas overcome by removing the primary infections to a location
where reinfection was impossible as at Dagshai.

In this country, Dr. Bass and Dr. H.H. Howard have made
an effort to calculate the relapse rate. Dr. Bass and Dr. Dedwylder
have a very large group to deal with, but their results are
deductions by inference. They calculate the percentage of
new infections by determining the number of cases of malaria which
occurred in a group of persons who gave negative histories for the
preceding year, and apply this percentage to the persons who did
have malaria the preceding year. It is questionable whether the two
groups lived under equal conditions of exposure to new
infections. A priori one might reason that those who had malaria
the preceding year where those persons so located as to have
maximum exposure and vice versa for the group with negative histories.
I believe that even in the Delta a careful study would show that
the distribution of malaria is not uniform,- that there are definite
foci of infection where the rate is high,- on a single plantation,-
perhaps, or even a single part of a plantation,- while the rate is
very low or perhaps only relapses occur in a neighboring plantation.
If then, our group of negative histories represented those persons
living in the areas where there was very little exposure to malaria,
the 241 cases might be very much more than
10% of those actually exposed to new infections. This, and the fact
that he is dealing with negro “histories” render the data uncertain.

Dr. Howard, delt with a very small group, 108 positive
smears in his controlled area and 37 positives in his non-controlled
area. He speaks only of “apparent relapses”, meaning by this
persons who had “definite attacks” of malaria during the preceding
season,- as ascertained by clinical histories usually confirmed.
In 1919, of 33 positive smears in the controlled area, he classes
20 as “new infections” and 13 as “relapses” (40% relapse rate).
In 1920, of 31 positive smears in his controlled area, he classes
12 and “new” and 19 as “relapses” (61% relapse rate). These
figures are very small and chance variation might modify them
considerably. Moreover, the “apparent relapses” may contain
a considerable number of reinfections and the “new cases” may
contain a considerable number of the previous seasons undiscovered
infections. In his uncontrolled area, he found in 1919,
14 “new” and 8 "relapses; in 1920, 21 “new” and 22 “relapses”.
In other words, all of the clinical cases discovered in 1919
must have relapsed in 1920, or there was re-infection to balance
every case of recovery. If the latter hypothesis is true, I
would surmise that his “relapses” might contain a considerable group
of re-infections, and a matter of two or three would change
the percentage considerably.

The method which you propose for approaching this
problem would insure the same conditions of exposure for all.
Up to May, we would be fairly sure of small risk of reinfection;
it would not be practical to protect a large group artificially
after the first flight of Anopheles. On the positive side
then, we could show the proportion which relapse up to the time
of the first flight; on the negative side, the proportion of the original portions which
- 4 -
remain apparently free from malaria as determined clinically and
by repeated examinations throughout the following season.
Obviously the negative group is of greater value than the positive.
The positive group would contain a large part of the tertian relapses but not the
aestivo-autumnal. The negative grooup, on the other hand,
after the first flight, would be constantly depleted by new
infections. (or relapse?). The first would give us the
lower limit or relapses; the second (subtracting the total number
of negatives surviving at then end of the second season from the
original total positives) would give the upper limit.

As to the original total negatives, part are those
missed by the technique of the examination and part are those
who harbor the parasite in their bodies but not in the sufficient
numbers in the peripheral blood at the time of the examination
to be discoverable by the method. The first error could be
determined by making an original examination, fixing the per cent
of positives, retaining all the negatives for repeated examination
by other observers to thus pick up any positive that were missed
on the original examination,- and finally comparing the original
total positives with the corrected total positives. The second
error, as you suggest would appear in the number of these
“negatives” (corrected) who relapsed before the Spring flight,-
at least in part,- for here again, would we get the aestivo-
autumnal relapses?.

In my studies here in Alabama, I am finding the
disease extremely focal in character. I am hoping to
find some isolated focus with the Anopheline production
centered in a single pond which can be readily and completely
controlled. If I could locate such a place, it might
-5-
be possible to control the breeding during the second season and
follow through without the complication of “new infections”.
I have in mind a place in Pike County to investigate for this purpose.

I hope you will be able to locate a copy of the equation
which you evolved for determining the proportion of infections
missed by careful examination. The article from Pearl's
department by Anthony Lotka was, - I confess - too deep for me.
I could not sustain my interest. All of the values with which
he starts are “unknowns” and I do not see any prospect of their
becoming “known” in the near future. I cannot seem to take the
mathematicians delight in dealing so at length with the abstract,-
to no apparent practical purpose beyond the mental gymnastics involved.

I am enclosing a preliminary table of the results of
Dr. Coogle's work in Mississippi this past winter. You will
note the spleen rate is considerably larger than the parasite rate.
The slides were examined by Miss Barrier in Dr. Krauss' laboratory,-
thick smear technique. I am getting up a little report of this
for the Public Healt Reports.

I hope I have not tired you by this long-winded letter,
but I wanted to be sure I understood the problem, and hope you will
write me again when you feel able and have a little spare time to chat.
Please thank Miss Laura for me. I am sending copies of your letter
and memorandum.

With all best wishes for your continued improvement
and complete recovery of your strength, I am
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Kenneth Maxcy (over)
C1
B21
P.S. at first opportunity I will discuss
with Dr. Fricks and Dr. Barter the
problem which you have so kindly
suggested and, if they agree,
we will try to set the conditions of the
experiment.
KTM
